If $G$ is bipartite then $\mathrm{ex}(n;G)\ll n^{3/2}$ if and only $G$ is $2$-degenerate, that is, $G$ contains no induced subgraph with minimal degree at least 3.



Conjectured by Erd\H{o}s and Simonovits \cite{ErSi84}. Erd\H{o}s first offered \$250 for a proof and \$100 for a counterexample, but in \cite{Er93} offered \$500 for a counterexample.

Disproved by Janzer \cite{Ja23b} who constructed, for any $\epsilon>0$, a $3$-regular bipartite graph $H$ such that\[\mathrm{ex}(n;H)\ll n^{\frac{4}{3}+\epsilon}.\]See also [146] and [147] and the entry in the graphs problem collection.




References


[Er93] Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Some of my favorite solved and unsolved problems in graph
theory. Quaestiones Math. (1993), 333-350.

[ErSi84] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Simonovits, M., Cube-supersaturated graphs and related problems. Progress in graph theory (Waterloo, Ont., 1982) (1984), 203-218.

[Ja23b] Janzer, Oliver, Disproof of a conjecture of {E}rd\H{o}s and {S}imonovits on the
{T}ur\'an number of graphs with minimum degree 3. Int. Math. Res. Not. IMRN (2023), 8478--8494.
